awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Rapid Innovations in SystEms Engineering and Agricultural Sustainability (RiseEnAg)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

The projected global increase to 9 billion people by the year 2050 will impose significant challenges on our ability to produce enough food for the world's population. Specific challenges that hinder our ability to meet the world's food security needs include: 1) our inability to sense and quantify, in a strategic way, physical and chemical variables in the environment and in-planta across scales; 2) the lack of scalable data analytics and multi-scale models that transform concurrent datasets across multiple scales into decision making strategies for improving crop yield and minimizing crop loss; and 3) the lack of intelligent data cyber-infrastructures that efficiently integrate heterogeneous data, supporting the development of complex multi-scale biological models. This planning grant will be used to support the development of an Engineering Research Center Proposal on Rapid Innovations in SystEms Engineering and Agricultural Sustainability (RiseEnAg).  The proposed Engineering Research Center will use convergent research to accelerate engineering innovation in plant sensor development, data analytics, and data integration via three synergistic research thrusts: 1) Sensor Development, Calibration, and Integration; 2) Data Mining, Machine Learning, and Multi-scale Modeling; and 3) Data Management and Integrative Cyberinfrastructures.  Phenotyping testbeds will be engineered to induce complex growth conditions and monitor biological and chemical responses. These "tools of discovery" will address the challenges of today's growers by translating real-time knowledge of crop and soil health and an increased understanding of relationships across the biological scale, into actionable strategies that advance crop field performance, increase post-harvesting longevity, and minimize post- harvest biomass loss.  The RiseEnAg Engineering Research Center will aim to target a complex grand challenge (food security) and defines the convergent space of research that merges the ideas, approaches, and technologies from engineering and the biological sciences needed to address it 

The goal of the RiseEnAg convergent engineering research center is to establish engineered systems platforms that integrate advanced sensors, data analytics, and phenotyping testbeds that address stakeholder (e.g. growers, researchers, and industry) challenges and accelerate research towards the goal of increased food security in the 21st century.  RiseEnAg will develop the engineering tools needed to achieve this goal via three integrated research thrusts.  Research Thrust 1 (Sensor Development, Calibration, and Integration) will develop and employ sensors for monitoring physical, chemical, biochemical, and molecular parameters, both in-planta and in the environment, to include rhizosphere microbiota-chemical interactomes that are key to plant performance.  Research Thrust 2 (Data Mining, Machine Learning, and Multiscale Modeling) will develop scalable modeling and machine learning algorithms for formulating integrative plant analytics and building decision support systems for growers.  Research Thrust 3 (Data Management and Integrative Cyberinfrastructures) will develop a robust, adaptable, and scalable framework for storing, accessing, and analyzing heterogeneous biological datasets.  High-throughput phenotyping plant growth testbeds will be engineered to induce complex growth conditions and monitor biological and chemical responses in-planta and in the soil.  These testbeds will accelerate the identification of novel biological and environmental targets that, when manipulated individually or in combination, can produce the desired performance outcomes under diverse growth conditions. Funds allocated via this planning grant will provide the resources needed to 1) explore and identify unique and common challenges across all stakeholders that, if addressed, accelerate us toward the common goal of agricultural sustainability, 2) identify novel areas of engineering that can contribute to addressing these problems and target potential roadblocks where innovation is needed, 3) outline specific goals for the remaining three fundamental components of the CERC (Engineering Workforce Development, Innovation Ecosystem, and Culture of Inclusion), and 4) formulate working draft of the final CERC proposal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The projected global population increase to 9 billion by 2050 presents significant challenges in ensuring an adequate food supply for the world. While agricultural advancements have been made, the current lack of sensing, data integration, and data management tools in the agricultural community hinders the generation of actionable strategies for achieving yield goals in 21st-century agriculture. This planning grant introduces the vision of the Engineering Research Center for Rapid Innovation in Systems Engineering and Agricultural Sustainability (RiseEnAg). The center's vision is to drive innovation, discovery, and education in sustainable agricultural technology, with a focus on addressing food security challenges. The strategic plan aligns research, inclusivity, engineering workforce development, and innovation ecosystem activities to bridge scientific gaps (multiscale sensing, phenotyping, data integration), technical gaps (automation, data access, on-field scalability), and social barriers (social acceptance, grower adoption, privacy) that hinder risk assessment and decision support for stakeholders. The goal of this planning grant is to enhance the capacity of the engineering academic community to foster ideas, support team formation, and strengthen relationships among stakeholders to realize this vision.

This planning grant concentrates on four specific goals: 1) Identifying problems with significant societal impact; 2) Defining a convergent research space with the appropriate personnel to address scientific and technical gaps; 3) Engaging with agricultural producers, growers, and biotechnology companies to explore how emerging technology can enhance their industry; and 4) Recognizing opportunities for team formation and leadership and management training.

In the initial stages of the grant, Stakeholder Engagement Workshops were held. These workshops involved producers, growers, and agricultural biotechnology company representatives. Qualitative analysis of the workshop results revealed that innovations in cost-effective sensor development, data acquisition, data management, data analytics, and data visualization have the potential to address key agricultural issues such as pests, diseases, and environmental fluctuations affecting growing conditions. Concerns included cost and the need to understand the technology. Stakeholders also emphasized the importance of sensor and data management technologies for crop management, yield monitoring, and improving sustainability. Fostering technology adoption and training extension agents were recurring themes. Day 2 participants discussed opportunities and barriers for industry-academia collaboration, including internships, local consortia, and industry involvement in graduate student committees.

RiseEnAg-affiliated faculty utilized the workshop outcomes to form teams for large-scale funding applications. These applications included grants from the National Science Foundation and the U.S. Department of Agriculture, several of which involved university research and ag- stakeholders from outside North Carolina. These grants expanded the participation of faculty from different universities, departments, and disciplines, resulting in numerous collaborative grant applications.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, large-scale follow-up workshops were limited, leading to one-on-one interviews with North Carolina ag-producers, focusing on the sweetpotato industry due to its prominence in the state. Twenty-eight interviews across the sweetpotato value chain were conducted. Stakeholders expressed a need for a user-friendly user interface available on smartphones and laptops, in English and Spanish, with automated data collection. They were particularly interested in solutions for storage, inventory management, and packing, while concerns included data privacy and unintended data use. Stakeholders sought technology that wouldn't benefit competitors, both domestic and foreign. Growers were keen on using environmental data for planting and harvesting decisions, while packers and distributors sought to improve storage practices and inventory management. The data collected could also serve as a valuable negotiating tool for buyers and sellers.

The ongoing partnership with major data service providers in the agricultural analytics field has led to pilot projects for cloud architectures to store, manage, and analyze diverse agricultural data. A pilot data management and compute cloud environment has been established in Azure for data analysis. Funding has been secured for the development of an Ag-Analytics Platform for the College of Agricultural and Life Sciences at NC State, with collaborative efforts from NC A&T State University. Relationships with other data service providers have also been initiated. Additionally, a collaborative project with BASF and NC State is focused on machine learning and deep learning algorithms for predicting soybean yield. The RiseEnAg team has actively engaged industry partners and hosted events, such as the Ag Innovation Forum and a machine learning track with Bayer for the N.C. Plant Sciences Initiative Hackathon.

These efforts have provided training opportunities for numerous undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers, involving workshops, data analysis, web-based tool development, dissemination of data analytics opportunities in the value chain, and the creation of tutorial and learning materials. 

Overall, our work outlines an approach for developing interdisciplinary projects that propose technology solutions that have the potential to directly impact ag- stakeholders.  The approach uses engagement as a primary tool to assess stakeholder concerns and increase technology adoption.  Current funded projects are being used as the basis for expanding proofs of concept to other ag- stakeholders from diverse cropping systems.
